Context:
Program Name: Business – Human Resources
Code: B134
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,498.00 *
International Tuition: $17,496.00 **
Location: St. James Campus
Program Availability:
- Fall 2023: Closed for domestic and international students
- Winter 2024: Closed for domestic and international students
Related Programs: Human Resources Management (Postgraduate) (B408), Business Administration – Human Resources (B144), Business Administration – Human Resources (with work experience) (B154)
Program Description: The Business – Human Resources program provides a practical approach to human resources management, preparing students for careers in this growing field. The learning experience enables students to design human resources policies and programs that adhere to employment legislation, attract, retain and develop a productive workforce, manage employee diversity, ensure health and safety at the workplace, and advise on employee/labour issues.
* Domestic tuition is for Canadian citizens or permanent residents.
** International tuition is for students requiring a study permit.

Context:
* The text mentions several programs offered at George Brown College's School of Human Resources, specifically the Centre for Business program.
* This program is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP).
* ACBSP has accredited 14 diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs offered at George Brown College's Schools of Accounting & Finance, HR, Management, and Marketing.
* The text provides a link to contact the Human Resources Professional Association of Ontario for information about obtaining professional designations in HR.
* Centre for Business students are required to bring their own laptops due to George Brown College's Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative.
* Field education opportunities are provided to students in addition to on-the-job work experience.
* Graduates of the program can find employment in areas such as recruitment and selection, compensation, benefits administration, human resources customer service, career planning and development.
* The B134 program requires completion of 27 courses, including 23 mandatory courses.
* There is a pathway to the Business Administration – Human Resources three-year advanced diploma program (B144/B154).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business – Human Resources Program B134 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The B134 program requires completion of 27 courses, including 23 mandatory courses, 1 Business Elective, and 3 General Education Electives. Students may be required to take additional courses like COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation), which do not count towards the 27 required courses and will incur extra charges.

Students need to complete three General Education courses from at least two categories: Social Sciences, Arts and Humanities, or Science and Technology. Students must make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation and can do so during the day or through Continuing Education, with assistance from business office staff.

Courses offered in Semester 1 include BUS 1038 (Business Concepts I), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts), COMP 1010 (Business Computer Applications), HRM 1029 (Principles of Human Resource Management I), MARK 1020 (Principles of Marketing I), and MATH 1008 (Math for Business & Management I).

Courses offered in Semester 2 include ACCT 1036 (Principles of Accounting), BUS 1040 (Project Management), COMM 1034 (Professional Communications I), HRM 2004 (Human Resources Info Systems), and HRM 1030 (Principles Of Human Resource Management II). Students need to meet the prerequisites for each course.

No specific year or email information was provided in the text.

- MATH 1095 (Math for Business & Management II)

- LAW 1006 (Employment and Human Rights Law)

- HSAF 1001 (Workplace Health & Safety)

- Select Field Education Course or Business Elective

General Education Electives:
- Electives
- Business Electives

Business Electives:
- BUS 1044 (Business Law, no pre-requisite)
- COMP 1113 (Principles of E-Business)

- MARK 2053 (Negotiation Skills, no pre-requisite)

Notes:
- Students are recommended to take Microeconomics and/or Macroeconomics as a business elective.
- HR courses have been approved by the Human Resources Professional Association of Ontario (HRPA).
- Students may choose to pursue an HRPA designation offered by them.

Context:
The text provides information on various courses offered in a Human Resources program at George Brown College. Some of the courses mentioned are: COMM 1034, MARK 2053, Negotiation Skills, MGMT 4009, Operations Management, MATH 1095, ECON 1031 (Microeconomics), BUS 1067 (Field Education), HRM 2023 (Labour Relations), HRM 1030, and ECON 1032 (Macroeconomics). The text also includes the program learning outcomes and tuition & fees information.

The graduate of this program is expected to be able to participate in various human resources processes such as recruitment, selection and retention of employees, performance management, planning and delivering training programs, contributing to organizational success through effective employee relations, assisting with administration and communication of compensation plans, following organizational health and safety policies, applying emerging information technologies to support the human resources function, implementing organizational development strategies, communicating HR information effectively, planning personal professional development, identifying HR components in a business plan, and assisting in collection and analysis of HR data.

The domestic tuition for the first two semesters of the program is $4,498 and international tuition is $17,496. It's important to note that fees are subject to change for programs starting at later dates. The text also mentions that this program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets eligibility criteria.

There's no specific information on application process, names or emails mentioned in the text.

Context: Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with a grade 12 English (C or U) and either grade 11 math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students (19 years old and above without OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to get required credits. Some college and university credits may grant course exemptions. George Brown College has English language proficiency requirements. International applicants should refer to country-specific admission requirements on the International Admissions page, apply through the Online Application System, and attend information sessions. Domestic students should apply via Ontario Colleges, contact the Admissions Office for queries about domestic admissions, and visit the Admission section. For financial inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office.
